that would be regarded today as physics, biology and other natural sciences.</sentence> <sentence>In modern times, the scope of<space/><italics>philosophy</italics><space/>has become limited to more generic or abstract inquiries, such as ethics and metaphysics, in which logic plays a major role.</sentence> <sentence>Today's philosophy tends to exclude empirical study of the natural world by means of the<space/><link><target>scientific method</target></link>.</sentence> <sentence>In contrast, <link synthetic="true"><target>Aristotle</target><part>Aristotle's</part></link> philosophical endeavors encompassed virtually all facets of intellectual inquiry.</sentence></paragraph><paragraph><sentence>In the larger sense of the word, <link synthetic="true"><target>Aristotle</target></link> makes philosophy coextensive with reasoning, which he also would describe as "science".</sentence> <sentence>Note, however, that his use of the term<space/><italics>science</italics><space/>carries a different meaning than that covered by the term "<link><target>scientific method</target></link>".</sentence> <sentence>For <link synthetic="true"><target>Aristotle</target></link>, "all science (<italics>dianoia</italics>) is either practical, poetical or theoretical" (<italics><link synthetic="true"><target>Metaphysics</target></link></italics><space/>1025b25).</sentence> <sentence>By practical science, he means ethics and politics; by poetical science, he means the study of poetry and the other fine arts; by theoretical science, he means physics,<space/><link><target>mathematics</target></link><space/>and metaphysics.</sentence></paragraph><paragraph><sentence>If logic (or "analytics") is regarded as a study preliminary to philosophy, the divisions of <link synthetic="true"><target>Aristotelianism</target><part>Aristotelian philosophy</part></link> would consist of: (1)<space/><link><target>Logic</target></link>; (2) Theoretical <link synthetic="true"><target>Ancient philosophy</target><part>Philosophy</part></link>, including <link synthetic="true"><target>Metaphysics</target></link>, <link synthetic="true"><target>Physics</target></link>, <link synthetic="true"><target>mathematics</target><part>Mathematics</part></link>, (3) Practical <link synthetic="true"><target>Ancient philosophy</target><part>Philosophy</part></link> and (4) Poetical <link synthetic="true"><target>Ancient philosophy</target><part>Philosophy</part></link>.</sentence></paragraph><paragraph><sentence>In the period between his two stays in <link synthetic="true"><target>Athens</target></link>, between his times at the <link synthetic="true"><target>Platonic Academy</target><part>Academy</part></link> and the <link synthetic="true"><target>Lyceum</target></link>, <link synthetic="true"><target>Aristotle</target></link> conducted most of the scientific thinking and research for which he is renowned today.</sentence> <sentence>In fact, most of <link synthetic="true"><target>Aristotle</target><part>Aristotle's</part></link> life was devoted to the study of the objects of natural science.</sentence> <sentence><link synthetic="true"><target>Aristotle</target><part>Aristotle's</part></link> metaphysics contains observations on the nature of numbers but he made no original contributions to mathematics.</sentence> <sentence>He did, however, perform<space/><link><target>original research</target></link><space/>in the natural sciences, e.g., botany, zoology, physics, astronomy, chemistry, meteorology, and several other sciences.</sentence></paragraph><paragraph><sentence><link synthetic="true"><target>Aristotle</target><part>Aristotle's</part></link> writings on science are largely qualitative, as opposed to quantitative.</sentence> <sentence>Beginning in the sixteenth century, scientists began applying mathematics to the physical sciences, and <link synthetic="true"><target>Aristotle</target><part>Aristotle's</part></link> work in this area was deemed hopelessly inadequate.</sentence> <sentence>His failings were largely due to the absence of concepts like mass, velocity, force and temperature.</sentence> <sentence>He had a conception of speed and temperature, but no quantitative understanding of them, which was partly due to the absence of basic experimental devices, like clocks and thermometers.</sentence><sentence><link><target>File:Perseid Meteor.jpg</target><part>thumb</part><part>A green and red<space/><link><target>Perseids</target><part>Perseid</part></link><space/>meteor is striking the sky just below the Milky Way in August 2007.</part></link>His writings provide an account of many scientific observations, a mixture of precocious accuracy and curious errors.</sentence> <sentence>For example, in his<space/><italics><link><target>History of Animals</target></link></italics><space/>he claimed that human males have more teeth than females.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref">Aristotle,<space/><italics>History of Animals</italics>, 2.3.</extension><space/><sentence>In a similar vein,<space/><link><target>John Philoponus</target></link>, and later<space/><link><target>Galileo Galilei</target><part>Galileo</part></link>, showed by simple experiments that <link synthetic="true"><target>Aristotle</target><part>Aristotle's</part></link> theory that a heavier object falls faster than a lighter object is incorrect.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref"><link type="external" href="http://plato.stanford.edu/entries/philoponus/#2.2">Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy</link></extension><space/><sentence>On the other hand, <link synthetic="true"><target>Aristotle</target></link> refuted<space/><link><target>Democritus</target></link>'s claim that the<space/><link><target>Milky Way</target></link><space/>was made up of "those stars which are shaded by the earth from the sun's rays," pointing out (correctly, even if such reasoning was bound to be dismissed for a long time) that, given "current astronomical demonstrations" that "the size of the sun is greater than that of the earth and the distance of the stars from the earth many times greater than that of the sun, then...the sun shines on all the stars and the earth screens none of them.</sentence>"<extension extension_name="ref">Aristotle,<space/><italics>Meteorology</italics><space/>1.8, trans. E.W. Webster, rev. J. Barnes.</extension></paragraph><paragraph><sentence>In places, <link synthetic="true"><target>Aristotle</target></link> goes too far in deriving 'laws of the universe' from simple observation and over-stretched<space/><link><target>reason</target></link>.</sentence> <sentence>Today's<space/><link><target>scientific method</target></link><space/>assumes that such thinking without sufficient facts is ineffective, and that discerning the validity of one's hypothesis requires far more rigorous experimentation than that which <link synthetic="true"><target>Aristotle</target></link> used to support his laws.</sentence></paragraph><paragraph><sentence><link synthetic="true"><target>Aristotle</target></link> also had some scientific blind spots.</sentence> <sentence>He posited a geocentric cosmology that we may discern in selections of the<space/><italics><link synthetic="true"><target>Metaphysics</target></link></italics>, which was widely accepted up until the 1500s.</sentence> <sentence>From the 3rd century to the 1500s, the dominant view held that the <link synthetic="true"><target>Earth (classical element)</target><part>Earth</part></link> was the center of the universe (<link><target>geocentrism</target></link>).</sentence></paragraph><paragraph><sentence>Since he was perhaps the philosopher most respected by European thinkers during and after the <link synthetic="true"><target>Renaissance</target></link>, these thinkers often took <link synthetic="true"><target>Aristotle</target><part>Aristotle's</part></link> erroneous positions as given, which held back science in this epoch.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref"><link><target>John Burnet (classicist)</target><part>Burent, John.</part></link><space/>1928.<space/><italics>Platonism</italics>, Berkeley: University of California Press, pp. 61, 103-104.</extension><space/><sentence>However, <link synthetic="true"><target>Aristotle</target><part>Aristotle's</part></link> scientific shortcomings should not mislead one into forgetting his great advances in the many scientific fields.</sentence> <sentence>For instance, he founded logic as a formal science and created foundations to biology that were not superseded for two millennia.</sentence> <sentence>Moreover, he introduced the fundamental notion that nature is composed of things that change and that studying such changes can provide useful knowledge of underlying constants.</sentence></paragraph><heading level="2">Physics</heading><paragraph><template name="main">\n<param name="1">Physics (Aristotle)</param>\n</template></paragraph><heading level="3">The five elements</heading><paragraph><template name="main">\n<param name="1">Classical element</param>\n</template></paragraph><list type="bullet"><listitem><sentence><link><target>Fire (classical element)</target><part>Fire</part></link>, which is hot and dry.</sentence></listitem><listitem><sentence><link><target>Earth (classical element)</target><part>Earth</part></link>, which is cold and dry.</sentence></listitem><listitem><sentence><link><target>Air (classical element)</target><part>Air</part></link>, which is hot and wet.</sentence></listitem><listitem><sentence><link><target>Water (classical element)</target><part>Water</part></link>, which is cold and wet.</sentence></listitem><listitem><sentence><link><target>Aether (classical element)</target><part>Aether</part></link>, which is the divine substance that makes up the heavenly spheres and heavenly bodies (stars and planets).</sentence></listitem></list><paragraph><sentence>Each of the four earthly elements has its natural place; the earth at the centre of the universe, then water, then air, then fire.</sentence> <sentence>When they are out of their natural place they have natural motion, requiring no external cause, which is towards that place; so bodies sink in water, air bubbles up, rain falls, flame rises in air.</sentence> <sentence>The heavenly element has perpetual circular motion.</sentence></paragraph><heading level="3">Causality, The Four Causes</heading><paragraph><template name="main">\n<param name="1">Four causes</param>\n</template></paragraph><list type="bullet"><listitem><sentence>The<space/><link><target>material cause</target></link><space/>is that from which a thing comes into existence as from its part, constituents, substratum or materials.</sentence> <sentence>This reduces the explanation of causes to the parts (factors, elements, constituents, ingredients) forming the whole (system, structure, compound, complex, composite, or combination), a relationship known as the part-whole causation.</sentence> <sentence>Simply put it is the influence of the material substances on the event.</sentence> <sentence>So imagine two dominos, the first of which is lighter.</sentence> <sentence><link synthetic="true"><target>The Divine Comedy</target><part>The first</part></link> is knocked over into the second but does not have enough power to knock it over, this is <link synthetic="true"><target>material cause</target><part>Material cause</part></link>.</sentence></listitem><listitem><sentence>The<space/><link><target>formal cause</target></link><space/>tells us what a thing is, that any thing is determined by the definition, form, pattern, essence, whole, synthesis or archetype.</sentence> <sentence>It embraces the account of causes in terms of fundamental principles or general laws, as the whole (i.e., macrostructure) is the cause of its parts, a relationship known as the whole-part causation.</sentence> <sentence>Plainly put it is the influence of the form (essence) of the things on the event.</sentence> <sentence>So take the two dominos again except this time the second is shaped to prevent it from falling *eg. triangular.* this is formal cause.</sentence></listitem><listitem><sentence>The<space/><link><target>efficient cause</target></link><space/>is that from which the change or the ending of the change first starts.</sentence> <sentence>It identifies 'what makes of what is made and what causes change of what is changed' and so suggests all sorts of agents, nonliving or living, acting as the sources of change or movement or rest.</sentence> <sentence>Representing the current understanding of causality as the relation of cause and effect, this covers the modern definitions of "cause" as either the agent or agency or particular events or states of affairs.</sentence> <sentence>More simply again that which immediately sets the thing in motion.</sentence> <sentence>So take the two dominos this time of equal weighting, the first is knocked over causing the second also to fall over.</sentence> <sentence>This is effectively efficient cause.</sentence></listitem><listitem><sentence>The<space/><link><target>final cause</target></link><space/>is that for the sake of which a thing exists or is done, including both purposeful and instrumental actions and activities.</sentence> <sentence>The final cause or telos is the purpose or end that something is supposed to serve, or it is that from which and that to which the change is.</sentence> <sentence>This also covers modern ideas of mental causation involving such psychological causes as volition, need, motivation, or motives, rational, irrational, ethical, all that gives purpose to behavior.</sentence></listitem></list><paragraph><sentence>Additionally, things can be causes of one another, causing each other reciprocally, as hard work causes fitness and vice versa, although not in the same way or function, the one is as the beginning of change, the other as the goal.</sentence> <sentence>(Thus <link synthetic="true"><target>Aristotle</target></link> first suggested a reciprocal or circular causality as a relation of mutual dependence or influence of cause upon effect).</sentence> <sentence>Moreover, <link synthetic="true"><target>Aristotle</target></link> indicated that the same thing can be the cause of contrary effects; its presence and absence may result in different outcomes.</sentence> <sentence>Simply it is the goal or purpose that brings about an event (not necessarily a mental goal).</sentence> <sentence>Taking our two dominos, it requires someone to intentionally knock the dominos over as they cannot fall themselves.</sentence></paragraph><paragraph><sentence><link synthetic="true"><target>Aristotle</target></link> marked two modes of causation: proper (prior) causation and accidental (chance) causation.</sentence> <sentence>All causes, proper and incidental, can be spoken as potential or as actual, particular or generic.</sentence> <sentence>The same language refers to the effects of causes, so that generic effects assigned to generic causes, particular effects to particular causes, operating causes to actual effects.</sentence> <sentence>Essentially, causality does not suggest a temporal relation between the cause and the effect.</sentence></paragraph><paragraph><sentence>All further investigations of causality will consist of imposing the favorite hierarchies on the order causes, such as final &gt; efficient &gt; material &gt; formal (<link><target>Thomas Aquinas</target></link>), or of restricting all causality to the material and efficient causes or to the efficient causality (deterministic or chance) or just to regular sequences and correlations of natural phenomena (the natural sciences describing how things happen instead of explaining the whys and wherefores).</sentence></paragraph><heading level="3">Chance and spontaneity</heading><paragraph><sentence>Spontaneity and chance are causes of effects.</sentence> <sentence>Chance as an incidental cause lies in the realm of<space/><link><target>sumbebekos</target><part>accidental things</part></link>.</sentence> <sentence>It is "from what is spontaneous" (but note that what is spontaneous does not come from chance).</sentence> <sentence>For a better understanding of <link synthetic="true"><target>Aristotle</target><part>Aristotle's</part></link> conception of "chance" it might be better to think of "coincidence": Something takes place by chance if a person sets out with the intent of having one thing take place, but with the result of another thing (not intended) taking place.</sentence> <sentence>For example: A person seeks donations.</sentence> <sentence>That person may find another person willing to donate a substantial sum.</sentence> <sentence>However, if the person seeking the donations met the person donating, not for the purpose of collecting donations, but for some other purpose, <link synthetic="true"><target>Aristotle</target></link> would call the collecting of the donation by that particular donator a result of chance.</sentence> <sentence>It must be unusual that something happens by chance.</sentence> <sentence>In other words, if something happens all or most of the time, we cannot say that it is by chance.</sentence></paragraph><paragraph><sentence>There is also more specific kind of chance, which <link synthetic="true"><target>Aristotle</target></link> names "luck", that can only apply to human beings, since it is in the sphere of moral actions.</sentence> <sentence>According to <link synthetic="true"><target>Aristotle</target></link>, luck must involve choice (and thus deliberation), and only humans are capable of deliberation and choice.</sentence> <sentence>"What is not capable of action cannot do anything by chance".</sentence><extension extension_name="ref">Aristotle,<space/><italics>Physics</italics><space/>2.6</extension></paragraph><heading level="2">Metaphysics</heading><paragraph><template name="main">\n<param name="1">Metaphysics (Aristotle)</param>\n</template><sentence><link synthetic="true"><target>Aristotle</target></link> defines metaphysics as "the knowledge of<space/><link><target>immaterial</target></link><space/>being," or of "being in the highest degree of abstraction."</sentence> <sentence>He refers to metaphysics as "first philosophy", as well as "the theologic science.</sentence>"</paragraph><heading level="3">Substance, potentiality and actuality</heading><paragraph><sentence><link synthetic="true"><target>Aristotle</target></link> examines the concept of substance and essence (<italics><link><target>ousia</target></link></italics>) in his<space/><italics><link synthetic="true"><target>Metaphysics</target></link></italics>, Book VII and he concludes that a particular substance is a combination of both matter and form.</sentence> <sentence>As he proceeds to the book VIII, he concludes that the matter of the substance is the<space/><link><target>substratum</target></link><space/>or the stuff of which it is composed,<space/><italics>e.g.</italics><space/>the matter of the house are the bricks, stones, timbers etc., or whatever constitutes the<space/><italics>potential</italics><space/>house.</sentence> <sentence>While the form of the substance, is the<space/><italics>actual</italics><space/>house, namely 'covering for bodies and chattels' or any other<space/><link><target>Genus-differentia definition</target><part>differentia</part></link><space/>(see also<space/><link><target>predicables</target></link>).</sentence> <sentence>The formula that gives the components is the account of the matter, and the formula that gives the differentia is the account of the form.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref">Aristotle,<space/><italics>Metaphysics</italics><space/>VIII 1043a 10-30</extension></paragraph><paragraph><sentence>With regard to the change (<italics><link><target>kinesis</target></link></italics>) and its causes now, as he defines in his<space/><link><target>Physics (Aristotle)</target><part>Physics</part></link><space/>and<space/><link><target>On Generation and Corruption</target></link><space/>319b-320a, he distinguishes the coming to be from: 1) growth and diminution, which is change in quantity; 2) locomotion, which is change in space; and 3) alteration, which is change in quality.</sentence></paragraph><paragraph><sentence>The coming to be is a change where nothing persists of which the resultant is a property.</sentence> <sentence>In that particular change he introduces the concept of<space/><link><target>Potentiality and actuality (Aristotle)</target><part>potentiality</part></link><space/>(<italics><link><target>dynamis</target></link></italics>) and<space/><link><target>Potentiality and actuality (Aristotle)</target><part>actuality</part></link><space/>(<italics><link><target>entelecheia</target></link></italics>) in association with the matter and the form.</sentence></paragraph><paragraph><sentence>Referring to potentiality, this is what a thing is capable of doing, or being acted upon, if it is not prevented by something else.</sentence> <sentence>For example, the seed of a plant in the soil is potentially (<italics>dynamei</italics>) plant, and if is not prevented by something, it will become a plant.</sentence> <sentence>Potentially beings can either 'act' (<italics><link><target>poiein</target></link></italics>) or 'be acted upon' (<italics><link><target>paschein</target></link></italics>), which can be either innate or learned.</sentence> <sentence>For example, the eyes possess the potentiality of sight (innate - being acted upon), while the capability of playing the flute can be possessed by learning (exercise - acting).</sentence></paragraph><paragraph><sentence><link synthetic="true"><target>Potentiality and actuality (Aristotle)</target><part>Actuality</part></link> is the fulfillment of the end of the potentiality.</sentence> <sentence>Because the end (<italics>telos</italics>) is the principle of every change, and for the sake of the end exists potentiality, therefore actuality is the end.</sentence> <sentence>Referring then to our previous example, we could say that actuality is when the seed of the plant becomes a plant.</sentence></paragraph><paragraph><sentence>" For that for the sake of which a thing is, is its principle, and the becoming is for the sake of the end; and the actuality is the end, and it is for the sake of this that the potentiality is acquired.</sentence> <sentence>For animals do not see in order that they may have sight, but they have sight that they may see.</sentence>"<extension extension_name="ref">Aristotle,<space/><italics>Metaphysics</italics><space/>IX 1050a 5-10</extension></paragraph><paragraph><sentence>In conclusion, the matter of the house is its potentiality and the form is its actuality.</sentence> <sentence>The<space/><link><target>formal cause</target></link><space/>(<italics>aitia</italics>) then of that change from potential to actual house, is the<space/><link><target>reason</target></link><space/>(<italics>logos</italics>) of the house builder and the<space/><link><target>final cause</target></link><space/>is the end, namely the house itself.</sentence> <sentence>Then <link synthetic="true"><target>Aristotle</target></link> proceeds and concludes that the actuality is prior to potentiality in formula, in time and in substantiality.</sentence></paragraph><paragraph><sentence>With this<space/><link><target>definition</target></link><space/>of the particular substance (i.e., matter and form), <link synthetic="true"><target>Aristotle</target></link> tries to solve the problem of the unity of the beings,<space/><italics>e.g.</italics>, what is that makes the man one?</sentence> <sentence>Since, according to <link synthetic="true"><target>Plato</target></link> there are two Ideas: animal and biped, how then is man a unity?</sentence> <sentence>However, according to <link synthetic="true"><target>Aristotle</target></link>, the potential being (matter) and the actual one (form) are one and the same thing.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref">Aristotle,<space/><italics>Metaphysics</italics><space/>VIII 1045a-b</extension></paragraph><heading level="3">Universals and particulars</heading><paragraph><template name="main">\n<param name="1">Aristotle's theory of universals</param>\n</template></paragraph><paragraph><sentence><link synthetic="true"><target>Aristotle</target><part>Aristotle's</part></link> predecessor, <link synthetic="true"><target>Plato</target></link>, argued that all things have a universal form, which could be either a property, or a relation to other things.</sentence> <sentence>When we look at an apple, for example, we see an apple, and we can also analyze a form of an apple.</sentence> <sentence>In this distinction, there is a particular apple and a universal form of an apple.</sentence> <sentence>Moreover, we can place an apple next to a book, so that we can speak of both the book and apple as being next to each other.</sentence></paragraph><paragraph><sentence><link synthetic="true"><target>Plato</target></link> argued that there are some universal forms that are not a part of particular things.</sentence> <sentence>For example, it is possible that there is no particular good in existence, but "good" is still a proper universal form.</sentence><space/><sentence><link><target>Bertrand Russell</target></link><space/>is a contemporary philosopher that agreed with <link synthetic="true"><target>Plato</target></link> on the existence of "uninstantiated universals".</sentence></paragraph><paragraph><sentence><link synthetic="true"><target>Aristotle</target></link> disagreed with <link synthetic="true"><target>Plato</target></link> on this point, arguing that all universals are instantiated.</sentence> <sentence><link synthetic="true"><target>Aristotle</target></link> argued that there are no universals that are unattached to existing things.</sentence> <sentence>According to <link synthetic="true"><target>Aristotle</target></link>, if a universal exists, either as a particular or a relation, then there must have been, must be currently, or must be in the future, something on which the universal can be predicated.</sentence> <sentence>Consequently, according to <link synthetic="true"><target>Aristotle</target></link>, if it is not the case that some universal can be predicated to an object that exists at some period of time, then it does not exist.</sentence></paragraph><paragraph><sentence>One way for contemporary philosophers to justify this position is by asserting the<space/><link><target>eleatic</target></link><space/>principle.</sentence></paragraph><paragraph><sentence>In addition, <link synthetic="true"><target>Aristotle</target></link> disagreed with <link synthetic="true"><target>Plato</target></link> about the location of universals.</sentence> <sentence>As <link synthetic="true"><target>Plato</target></link> spoke of the world of the forms, a location where all universal forms subsist, <link synthetic="true"><target>Aristotle</target></link> maintained that universals exist within each thing on which each universal is predicated.</sentence> <sentence>So, according to <link synthetic="true"><target>Aristotle</target></link>, the form of apple exists within each apple, rather than in the world of the forms.</sentence></paragraph><heading level="2">Biology and medicine</heading><paragraph><sentence>In <link synthetic="true"><target>Aristotelian physics</target><part>Aristotelian</part></link> science, most especially in biology, things he saw himself have stood the test of time better than his retelling of the reports of others, which contain error and superstition.</sentence> <sentence>He dissected animals, but not humans and his ideas on how the human body works have been almost entirely superseded.</sentence></paragraph><heading level="3">Empirical research program</heading><paragraph><sentence><link><target>File:Octo2.jpg</target><part>thumb</part><part>Octopus swimming</part></link><link><target>File:Torpedo fuscomaculata2.jpg</target><part>thumb</part><part>''Torpedo fuscomaculata''</part></link><link synthetic="true"><target>Aristotle</target></link> is the earliest natural historian whose work has survived in some detail.</sentence> <sentence><link synthetic="true"><target>Aristotle</target></link> certainly did research on the natural history of<space/><link><target>Lesbos</target></link>, and the surrounding seas and neighbouring areas.</sentence> <sentence>The works that reflect this research, such as<space/><italics><link><target>History of Animals</target></link></italics>,<space/><italics><link><target>Generation of Animals</target></link></italics>, and<space/><italics><link><target>Parts of Animals</target></link></italics>, contain some observations and interpretations, along with sundry myths and mistakes.</sentence> <sentence>The most striking passages are about the sea-life visible from observation on <link synthetic="true"><target>Lesbos Island</target><part>Lesbos</part></link> and available from the catches of fishermen.</sentence> <sentence>His observations on<space/><link><target>catfish</target></link>,<space/><link><target>Electric ray</target><part>electric fish</part></link><space/>(<link><target>Torpedo (genus)</target><part>Torpedo</part></link>) and angler-fish are detailed, as is his writing on<space/><link><target>cephalopod</target><trail>s</trail></link>, namely,<space/><italics><link><target>Octopus</target></link></italics>,<space/><italics>Sepia</italics><space/>(<link><target>cuttlefish</target></link>) and the paper nautilus (<italics><link><target>Argonauta argo</target></link></italics>).</sentence> <sentence>His description of the<space/><link><target>hectocotylus</target><part>hectocotyl arm</part></link><space/>was about two thousand years ahead of its time, and widely disbelieved until its rediscovery in the nineteenth century.</sentence> <sentence>He separated the aquatic mammals from fish, and knew that sharks and rays were part of the group he called Selachē (<link><target>selachians</target></link>).</sentence><extension extension_name="ref" name="Singer, Charles 1931">Singer, Charles.<space/><italics>A short history of biology</italics>. Oxford 1931.</extension></paragraph><paragraph><sentence><link><target>File:Triakis semifasciata.jpg</target><part>thumb</part><part>Leopard shark</part></link></sentence></paragraph><paragraph><sentence>Another good example of his methods comes from the<space/><italics><link synthetic="true"><target>Generation of Animals</target></link></italics><space/>in which <link synthetic="true"><target>Aristotle</target></link> describes breaking open fertilized chicken eggs at intervals to observe when visible organs were generated.</sentence></paragraph><paragraph><sentence>He gave accurate descriptions of<space/><link><target>ruminant</target><trail>s</trail></link>' four-chambered fore-stomachs, and of the<space/><link><target>Ovoviviparity</target><part>ovoviviparous</part></link><space/>embryological development of the<space/><link><target>hound shark</target></link><space/><italics><link><target>Mustelus mustelus</target></link></italics>.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref">Emily Kearns, "Animals, knowledge about," in<space/><italics><link><target>Oxford Classical Dictionary</target></link></italics>, 3rd ed., 1996, p. 92.</extension></paragraph><heading level="3">Classification of living things</heading><paragraph><sentence><link synthetic="true"><target>Aristotle</target><part>Aristotle's</part></link> classification of living things contains some elements which still existed in the nineteenth century.</sentence> <sentence>What the modern zoologist would call vertebrates and invertebrates, <link synthetic="true"><target>Aristotle</target></link> called 'animals with blood' and 'animals without blood' (he was not to know that complex invertebrates do make use of<space/><link><target>haemoglobin</target></link>, but of a different kind from vertebrates).</sentence> <sentence><link synthetic="true"><target>History of Animals</target><part>Animals</part></link> with blood were divided into live-bearing (humans and mammals), and egg-bearing (birds and fish).</sentence> <sentence>Invertebrates ('animals without blood') are insects, crustacea (divided into non-shelled – cephalopods – and shelled) and testacea (molluscs).</sentence> <sentence>In some respects, this incomplete classification is better than that of<space/><link><target>Linnaeus</target></link>, who crowded the invertebrata together into two groups, Insecta and Vermes (worms).</sentence></paragraph><paragraph><sentence>For<space/><link><target>Charles Singer</target></link>, "Nothing is more remarkable than [<link synthetic="true"><target>Aristotle</target><part>Aristotle's</part></link>] efforts to [exhibit] the relationships of living things as a<space/><italics>scala naturae</italics>"<extension extension_name="ref" name="Singer, Charles 1931"/><space/><link synthetic="true"><target>Aristotle</target><part>Aristotle's</part></link><space/><italics><link synthetic="true"><target>History of Animals</target></link></italics><space/>classified organisms in relation to a hierarchical "<link><target>Great chain of being</target><part>Ladder of Life</part></link>" (<italics>scala naturae</italics>), placing them according to complexity of structure and function so that higher organisms showed greater vitality and ability to move.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref">Aristotle, of course, is not responsible for the later use made of this idea by clerics.</extension></paragraph><paragraph><sentence><link synthetic="true"><target>Aristotle</target></link> believed that intellectual purposes, i.e.</sentence>,<space/><sentence><link><target>formal cause</target><trail>s</trail></link>, guided all natural processes.</sentence> <sentence>Such a<space/><link><target>teleological</target></link><space/>view gave <link synthetic="true"><target>Aristotle</target></link> cause to justify his observed data as an expression of formal design.</sentence> <sentence>Noting that "no animal has, at the same time, both tusks and horns," and "a single-hooved animal with two horns I have never seen," <link synthetic="true"><target>Aristotle</target></link> suggested that <link synthetic="true"><target>state of nature</target><part>Nature</part></link>, giving no animal both horns and tusks, was staving off vanity, and giving creatures faculties only to such a degree as they are necessary.</sentence> <sentence>Noting that ruminants had a multiple stomachs and weak teeth, he supposed the first was to compensate for the latter, with <link synthetic="true"><target>state of nature</target><part>Nature</part></link> trying to preserve a type of balance.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref">Mason,<space/><italics>A History of the Sciences</italics><space/>pp 43-44</extension></paragraph><paragraph><sentence>In a similar fashion, <link synthetic="true"><target>Aristotle</target></link> believed that creatures were arranged in a graded scale of perfection rising from plants on up to man, the<space/><italics>scala naturae</italics><space/>or<space/><link><target>Great Chain of Being</target></link>.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref">Mayr,<space/><italics>The Growth of Biological Thought</italics>, pp 201-202; see also: Lovejoy,<space/><italics>The Great Chain of Being</italics></extension><space/><sentence>His system had eleven grades, arranged according "to the degree to which they are infected with potentiality", expressed in their form at birth.</sentence> <sentence>The highest animals laid warm and wet creatures alive, the lowest bore theirs cold, dry, and in thick eggs.</sentence></paragraph><heading level="3">Theory of biological forms and souls</heading><paragraph><sentence><link synthetic="true"><target>Aristotle</target></link> also held that the level of a creature's perfection was reflected in its form, but not preordained by that form.</sentence> <sentence>Ideas like this, and his ideas about souls, are not regarded as science at all in modern times.</sentence></paragraph><paragraph><sentence>He placed emphasis on the type(s) of soul an organism possessed, asserting that plants possess a vegetative soul, responsible for reproduction and growth, animals a vegetative and a sensitive soul, responsible for mobility and sensation, and humans a vegetative, a sensitive, and a rational soul, capable of thought and reflection.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref">Aristotle,<space/><italics>De Anima</italics><space/>II 3</extension></paragraph><paragraph><sentence><link brain.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref">Mason,<space/><italics>A History of the Sciences</italics><space/>pp 45</extension><space/><sentence>Notable is <link synthetic="true"><target>Aristotle</target><part>Aristotle's</part></link> division of sensation and thought, which generally went against previous philosophers, with the exception of<space/><link><target>Alcmaeon of Croton</target><part>Alcmaeon</part></link>.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref">Guthrie,<space/><italics>A History of Greek Philosophy</italics><space/>Vol. 1 pp. 348</extension></paragraph><paragraph><sentence>His analysis of procreation is frequently criticized on the grounds that it presupposes an active, ensouling masculine element bringing life to an inert, passive, lumpen female element; it is on these grounds that <link synthetic="true"><target>Aristotle</target></link> is considered by some feminist critics to have been 252</extension></paragraph><heading level="2">Practical Philosophy</heading><heading level="3">Ethics</heading><paragraph><template name="main">\n<param name="1">Aristotelian than merely reasoning.</sentence> <sentence>Further, <link synthetic="true"><target>Aristotle</target></link> believed that ethical knowledge is not certain knowledge (such as metaphysics or<space/><link><target>epistemology</target></link>) but is general knowledge.</sentence> <sentence>He wrote several treatises on ethics, including most ethics</target></link>.</sentence></paragraph><paragraph><sentence><link synthetic="true"><target>Aristotle</target></link> taught that virtue has to do with the proper function of a thing.</sentence> <sentence>An eye is only a good eye in so much as it can see, because the proper function of an eye is sight.</sentence> <sentence><link synthetic="true"><target>Aristotle</target></link> reasoned that man must have a function uncommon to anything else, and that this function must be an activity of the soul.</sentence> <sentence><link synthetic="true"><target>Aristotle</target></link> identified the best activity of the soul as<space/><link><target>eudaimonia</target></link>: a happiness or joy that pervades the good life.</sentence> <sentence><link different persons and situations, and exists as a<space/><link><target>Golden mean (philosophy)</target><part>golden mean</part></link><space/>between two vices - one an excess and one a deficiency.</sentence></paragraph><heading level="3">Politics</heading><paragraph><template name="main">\n<param name="1">Politics (Aristotle)</param>\n</template><sentence>In addition to his works on he is considered one of the first to conceive of the city in this manner.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref"><template name="cite book">\n<param name="last">Ebenstein</param>\n<param article)</sentence></listitem><listitem><sentence>Scholarly surveys of focused topics from the<space/><italics><link><target>Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy</target></link></italics>: articles on<space/><link type="external" href="http://plato.stanford.edu/entries/aristotle/">Aristotle</link>,<space/><link type="external" topics">\n</template><template name="Logic">\n</template><template name="Philosophy topics">\n</template></paragraph><list type="bullet"><listitem><template name="planetmath">\n<param name="id">5840</param>\n<param name="title">Aristotle</param>\n</template></listitem></list><paragraph><template name="Persondata">\n<param name="NAME">Aristotle</param>\n<param name="ALTERNATIVE
