Mackenzie, p.215.</extension></paragraph><paragraph><sentence>The committee considered an eight-bit code, since eight bits would allow two four-bit patterns to efficiently encode two digits with<space/><link><target>binary coded decimal</target></link>.</sentence> <sentence>However this would require all data transmission to send eight bits when seven could suffice.</sentence> <sentence>The committee voted to use a seven-bit code to minimize costs associated with data transmission.</sentence> <sentence>Since perforated tape at the time could record eight bits in one position, this also allowed for a<space/><link><target>parity bit</target></link><space/>for error checking if desired.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref">Decision 5. Mackenzie, p.217.</extension><space/><sentence>Machines with<space/><link><target>octet (computing)</target><part>octets</part></link><space/>as the native data type that did not use parity checking typically set the eighth bit to<space/><italics>0</italics>.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref">Sawyer A. Sawyer and Steven George Krantz (January 1, 1995).<space/><italics>A Tex Primer for Scientists</italics>. CRC Press. ISBN 0-8493-7159-7. p.13.</extension></paragraph><paragraph><sentence>The code itself was structured so that most control codes were together, and all graphic codes were together.</sentence> <sentence>The first two columns (32 positions) were reserved for control characters.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref">Decision 8,9. Mackenzie, p.220.</extension><space/><sentence>The<space/><link><target>Space (punctuation)</target><part>"space" character</part></link><space/>had to come before graphics to make<space/><link><target>sorting algorithm</target><trail>s</trail></link><space/>easy, so it became position 32.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref">Decision 10. Mackenzie, p.237.</extension><space/><sentence>The committee decided it was important to support<space/><link><target>upper case</target></link><space/>64-character alphabets, and chose to structure <link synthetic="true"><target>ASCII</target></link> so it could easily be reduced to a usable 64-character set of graphic codes.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref">Decision 14. Mackenzie, p.228.</extension><space/><sentence><link><target>Lower case</target></link><space/>letters were therefore not interleaved with upper case.</sentence> <sentence>To keep options open for lower case letters and other graphics, the special and numeric codes were placed before the letters, and the letter 'A' was placed in position 65 to match the draft of the corresponding British standard.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref">Decision 18. Mackenzie, p.238.</extension><space/><sentence>The digits 0–9 were placed so they correspond to values in binary prefixed with 011, making conversion with<space/><link><target>binary-coded decimal</target></link><space/>straightforward.</sentence></paragraph><paragraph><sentence>Many of the non-alphanumeric characters were positioned to correspond to their shifted position on typewriters.</sentence> <sentence>Thus #, $ and % were placed to correspond to 3, 4, and 5 in the adjacent column.</sentence> <sentence>The parentheses could not correspond to 9 and 0, however, because the place corresponding to 0 was taken by the space character.</sentence> <sentence>Since many European typewriters placed the parentheses with 8 and 9, those corresponding positions were chosen for the parentheses.</sentence> <sentence>The @ symbol was not used in continental Europe and the committee expected it would be replaced by an accented À in the French variation, so the @ was placed in position 64 next to the letter A.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref">Mackenzie, p.243.</extension></paragraph><paragraph><sentence>The control codes felt essential for data transmission were the start of message (SOM), end of address (EOA), end of message (EOM), end of transmission (EOT), "who are you?"</sentence> <sentence>(WRU), "are you?"</sentence> <sentence>(RU), a reserved device control (DC0), synchronous idle (SYNC), and acknowledge (ACK).</sentence> <sentence>These were positioned to maximize the<space/><link><target>Hamming distance</target></link><space/>between their bit patterns.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref">Mackenzie, p.243-245.</extension></paragraph><paragraph><sentence>With the other special characters and control codes filled in, <link synthetic="true"><target>ASCII</target></link> was published as ASA X3.4-1963, leaving 28 code positions without any assigned meaning, reserved for future standardization, and one unassigned control code.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref">Mackenzie, p.66, 245.</extension><space/><sentence>It now seems obvious that these positions should have been assigned to the lower case alphabet, but there was some debate at the time whether there should be more control characters instead.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref">Mackenzie, p.435.</extension><space/><sentence>The indecision did not last long: in May 1963 the<space/><link><target>CCITT</target></link><space/>Working Party on the New <link synthetic="true"><target>telegraph</target><part>Telegraph</part></link> <link synthetic="true"><target>English alphabet</target><part>Alphabet</part></link> proposed to assign lower case characters to columns 6 and 7,<extension extension_name="ref">Brief Report: Meeting of CCITT Working Party on the New Telegraph Alphabet, May 13-15, 1963.</extension><space/>and<space/><link><target>International Organization for Standardization</target></link><space/>TC 97 SC 2 voted in October to incorporate the change into its draft standard.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref">Report of ISO/TC/97/SC 2 - Meeting of October 29-31, 1963.</extension><space/><sentence>The X3.2.4 task group voted its approval for the change to <link synthetic="true"><target>ASCII</target></link> at its May 1963 meeting.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref">Report on Task Group X3.2.4, June 11, 1963, Pentagon Building, Washington, DC.</extension><space/><sentence>Locating the lowercase letters in columns 6 and 7 caused the characters to differ in bit pattern from the upper case by a single bit, which simplified<space/><link><target>case-insensitive</target></link><space/>character matching and the construction of keyboards and printers.</sentence></paragraph><paragraph><sentence>The X3 committee made other changes, including other new characters (the<space/><link><target>bracket</target><part>curly bracket</part></link><space/>and vertical line characters),<extension extension_name="ref">Report of Meeting No. 8, Task Group X3.2.4, December 17 and 18, 1963</extension><space/>renaming some control characters (SOM became start of header (SOH)) and moving or removing others (RU was removed).</sentence><extension extension_name="ref">Mackenzie, p.247-8.</extension><space/><sentence><link synthetic="true"><target>ASCII</target></link> was subsequently updated as USASI X3.4-1967, then USASI X3.4-1968, <link synthetic="true"><target>ANSI escape code</target><part>ANSI</part></link> X3.4-1977, and finally, <link synthetic="true"><target>ANSI escape code</target><part>ANSI</part></link> X3.4-1986 (the first two are occasionally retronamed <link synthetic="true"><target>ANSI escape code</target><part>ANSI</part></link> X3.4-1967, and <link synthetic="true"><target>ANSI escape code</target><part>ANSI</part></link> X3.4-1968).</sentence></paragraph><paragraph><sentence>The X3 committee also addressed how <link synthetic="true"><target>ASCII</target></link> should be transmitted (least significant bit first), and how it should be recorded on perforated tape.</sentence> <sentence>They proposed a<space/><link><target>9-track</target></link><space/>standard for magnetic tape, and attempted to deal with some forms of<space/><link><target>punched card</target></link><space/>formats.</sentence></paragraph><paragraph><sentence><link synthetic="true"><target>ASCII</target></link> itself first entered commercial use in 1963 as a seven-bit teleprinter code for<space/><link><target>American Telephone &amp;amp; Telegraph</target></link>'s<space/><link><target>TWX</target></link><space/>(<link synthetic="true"><target>Teleprinter</target><part>Teletype</part></link> Wide-area eXchange) network.</sentence> <sentence><link synthetic="true"><target>TWX</target></link> originally used the earlier five-bit<space/><link><target>Baudot code</target></link>, which was also used by the competing<space/><link><target>Telex</target></link><space/>teleprinter system.</sentence><space/><sentence><link><target>Bob Bemer</target></link><space/>introduced features such as the escape sequence.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref" name="Brandel"/><space/><sentence>His British colleague<space/><link><target>Hugh McGregor Ross</target></link><space/>helped to popularize this work—according to <link synthetic="true"><target>Bob Bemer</target><part>Bemer</part></link>, "so much so that the code that was to become <link synthetic="true"><target>ASCII</target></link> was first called the <link synthetic="true"><target>Bob Bemer</target><part>Bemer</part></link>-<link synthetic="true"><target>Hugh McGregor Ross</target><part>Ross</part></link> <link synthetic="true"><target>telegraph</target><part>Code</part></link> in Europe".</sentence><extension extension_name="ref"><link><target>Bob Bemer</target></link><space/>(n.d.).<space/><link type="external" href="http://www.trailing-edge.com/~bobbemer/EUROPE.HTM">Bemer meets Europe</link>.<space/><italics>Trailing-edge.com</italics>. Accessed 2008-04-14. Employed at<space/><link><target>IBM</target></link><space/>at that time</extension></paragraph><paragraph><sentence>On March 11, 1968, U.S.</sentence> <sentence>President<space/><link><target>Lyndon B. Johnson</target></link><space/>mandated that all computers purchased by the <link synthetic="true"><target>United Kingdom</target><part>United</part></link> States federal government support <link synthetic="true"><target>ASCII</target></link>, stating:<extension extension_name="blockquote">I have also approved recommendations of the Secretary of Commerce regarding standards for recording the Standard Code for Information Interchange on magnetic tapes and paper tapes when they are used in computer operations.All computers and related equipment configurations brought into the Federal Government inventory on and after July 1, 1969, must have the capability to use the Standard Code for Information Interchange and the formats prescribed by the magnetic tape and paper tape standards when these media are used.<extension extension_name="ref"><link><target>Lyndon B. Johnson</target></link><space/>(March 11, 1968).<space/><link type="external" href="http://www.presidency.ucsb.edu/ws/index.php?pid=28724">Memorandum Approving the Adoption by the Federal Government of a Standard Code for Information Interchange</link>.<space/><italics>The American Presidency Project</italics>. Accessed 2008-04-14.</extension></extension></sentence></paragraph><paragraph><sentence>Other international standards bodies have ratified character encodings such as<space/><link><target>ISO/IEC 646</target></link><space/>that are identical or nearly identical to <link synthetic="true"><target>ASCII</target></link>, with extensions for characters outside the<space/><link><target>English alphabet</target></link><space/>and symbols used outside the <link synthetic="true"><target>United Kingdom</target><part>United</part></link> States, such as the symbol for the<space/><link><target>United Kingdom</target></link>'s<space/><link><target>pound sterling</target></link><space/>(£).</sentence> <sentence>Almost every country needed an adapted version of <link synthetic="true"><target>ASCII</target></link> since <link synthetic="true"><target>ASCII</target></link> only suited the needs of the USA and a few other countries.</sentence> <sentence>For example, Canada had its own version that supported French characters.</sentence> <sentence>Other adapted encodings include<space/><link><target>ISCII</target></link><space/>(India),<space/><link><target>VISCII</target></link><space/>(Vietnam), and<space/><link><target>YUSCII</target></link><space/>(Yugoslavia).</sentence> <sentence>Although these encodings are sometimes referred to as <link synthetic="true"><target>ASCII</target></link>, true <link synthetic="true"><target>ASCII</target></link> is strictly defined only by <link synthetic="true"><target>ANSI escape code</target><part>ANSI</part></link> standard.</sentence></paragraph><paragraph><sentence><link synthetic="true"><target>ASCII</target></link> was incorporated into the<space/><link><target>Unicode</target></link><space/>character set as the first 128 symbols, so the <link synthetic="true"><target>ASCII</target></link> characters have the same numeric codes in both sets.</sentence> <sentence>This allows<space/><link><target>UTF-8</target></link><space/>to be<space/><link><target>Backward compatibility</target><part>backward compatible</part></link><space/>with <link synthetic="true"><target>ASCII</target></link>, a significant advantage.</sentence></paragraph><paragraph><sentence>Asteroid<space/><link><target>3568 ASCII</target></link><space/>is named after the character encoding.</sentence></paragraph><heading level="2">ASCII control characters</heading><paragraph><template name="main">\n<param name="1">Control character</param>\n</template><sentence><link synthetic="true"><target>ASCII</target></link> reserves the first 32 codes (numbers 0–31 decimal) for<space/><link><target>control character</target><trail>s</trail></link>: codes originally intended not to carry printable information, but rather to control devices (such as<space/><link><target>computer printer</target><part>printer</part><trail>s</trail></link>) that make use of <link synthetic="true"><target>ASCII</target></link>, or to provide meta-information about data streams such as those stored on magnetic tape.</sentence> <sentence>For example, character 10 represents the "line feed" function (which causes a printer to advance its paper), and character 8 represents "backspace".</sentence> <sentence>RFC 2822 refers to control characters that do not include carriage return, line feed or white space as non-whitespace control characters.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref">RFC 2822 (April 2001). "NO-WS-CTL".</extension><space/><sentence>Except for the control characters that prescribe elementary line-oriented formatting, <link synthetic="true"><target>ASCII</target></link> does not define any mechanism for describing the structure or appearance of text within a document.</sentence> <sentence>Other schemes, such as<space/><link><target>markup language</target><trail>s</trail></link>, address page and document layout and formatting.</sentence></paragraph><paragraph><sentence>The original <link synthetic="true"><target>ASCII</target></link> standard used only short descriptive phrases for each control character.</sentence> <sentence>The ambiguity this left was sometimes intentional (where a character would be used slightly differently on a terminal link than on a data stream) and sometimes more accidental (such as what "delete" means).</sentence></paragraph><paragraph><sentence>Probably the most influential single device on the interpretation of these characters was the<space/><link><target>ASR-33 Teletype</target></link><space/>series, which was a printing terminal with an available<space/><link><target>punched tape</target><part>paper tape</part></link><space/>reader/punch option.</sentence> <sentence><link synthetic="true"><target>punched tape</target><part>Paper tape</part></link> was a very popular medium for long-term program storage up through the 1980s, lower cost and in some ways less fragile than magnetic tape.</sentence> <sentence>In particular, the <link synthetic="true"><target>Teleprinter</target><part>Teletype</part></link> 33 machine assignments for codes 17 (<link synthetic="true"><target>Control-@</target><part>Control-</part></link>Q, DC1, also known as <link synthetic="true"><target>XON/XOFF</target><part>XON</part></link>), 19 (<link synthetic="true"><target>Control-@</target><part>Control-</part></link>S, DC3, also known as <link synthetic="true"><target>XON/XOFF</target><part>XOFF</part></link>), and 127 (DELete) became de-facto standards.</sentence> <sentence>Because the keytop for the O key also showed a left-arrow symbol (from <link synthetic="true"><target>ASCII</target></link>-1963, which had this character instead of underscore), a noncompliant use of code 15 (<link synthetic="true"><target>Control-@</target><part>Control-</part></link>O, <link synthetic="true"><target>Shift Out and Shift In characters</target><part>Shift In</part></link>) interpreted as "delete previous character" was also adopted by many early timesharing systems but eventually faded out.</sentence></paragraph><paragraph><sentence>The use of <link synthetic="true"><target>Control-@</target><part>Control-</part></link>S (<link synthetic="true"><target>XON/XOFF</target><part>XOFF</part></link>, an abbreviation for "transmit off") as a handshaking signal warning a sender to stop transmission because of impending overflow, and <link synthetic="true"><target>Control-@</target><part>Control-</part></link>Q (<link synthetic="true"><target>XON/XOFF</target><part>XON</part></link>, "transmit on") to resume sending, persists to this day in many systems as a manual output control technique.</sentence> <sentence>On some systems <link synthetic="true"><target>Control-@</target><part>Control-</part></link>S retains its meaning but <link synthetic="true"><target>Control-@</target><part>Control-</part></link>Q is replaced by a second <link synthetic="true"><target>Control-@</target><part>Control-</part></link>S to resume output.</sentence></paragraph><paragraph><sentence><link synthetic="true"><target>telegraph</target><part>Code</part></link> 127 is officially named "delete" but the <link synthetic="true"><target>Teleprinter</target><part>Teletype</part></link> label was "rubout".</sentence> <sentence>Since the original standard gave no detailed interpretation for most control codes, interpretations of this code varied.</sentence> <sentence>The original <link synthetic="true"><target>Teleprinter</target><part>Teletype</part></link> meaning, and the intent of the standard, was to make it an ignored character, the same as NUL (all zeroes).</sentence> <sentence>This was specifically useful for<space/><link><target>punched tape</target><part>paper tape</part></link>, because punching the all-ones bit pattern on top of an existing mark would obliterate it.</sentence> <sentence><link synthetic="true"><target>punched tape</target><part>Tapes</part></link> designed to be "hand edited" could even be produced with spaces of extra NULs (blank tape) so that a block of characters could be "rubbed out" and then replacements put into the empty space.</sentence></paragraph><paragraph><sentence>As video terminals began to replace printing ones, the value of the "rubout" character was lost.</sentence> <sentence><link synthetic="true"><target>Digital Equipment Corporation</target><part>DEC</part></link> systems, for example, interpreted "Delete" to mean "remove the character before the cursor," and this interpretation also became common in Unix systems.</sentence> <sentence>Most other systems used "<link synthetic="true"><target>Backspace</target></link>" for that meaning and used "Delete" to mean "remove the character at the cursor".</sentence> <sentence>That latter interpretation is the most common today.</sentence></paragraph><paragraph><sentence>Many more of the control codes have taken on meanings quite different from their original ones.</sentence> <sentence>The "escape" character (code 27), for example, was originally intended to allow sending other control characters as literals instead of invoking their meaning.</sentence> <sentence>This is the same meaning of "escape" encountered in URL encodings, C language strings, and other systems where certain characters have a reserved meaning.</sentence> <sentence>Over time this meaning has been co-opted and has eventually drifted.</sentence> <sentence>In modern use, an ESC sent to the terminal usually indicates the start of a command sequence, usually in the form of a so-called "<link><target>ANSI escape code</target></link>" (or, more properly, a "<link synthetic="true"><target>control character</target><part>Control</part></link> Sequence Introducer") beginning with ESC followed by a "[" (left-bracket) character.</sentence> <sentence>An ESC sent from the terminal is most often used as an "out of band" character used to terminate an operation, as in the<space/><link><target>Text Editor and Corrector</target><part>TECO</part></link><space/>and<space/><link><target>vi</target></link><space/>text editors.</sentence></paragraph><paragraph><sentence>The inherent ambiguity of many control characters, combined with their historical usage, created problems when transferring "plain text" files between systems.</sentence> <sentence>The clearest example of this is the<space/><link><target>newline</target></link><space/>problem on various<space/><link><target>operating system</target><trail>s</trail></link>.</sentence> <sentence>On printing terminals there is no question that you terminate a line of text with both "<link synthetic="true"><target>carriage return</target><part>Carriage Return</part></link>" and "Linefeed".</sentence> <sentence>The first returns the printing carriage to the beginning of the line and the second advances to the next line without moving the carriage.</sentence> <sentence>However, requiring two characters to mark the end of a line introduced unnecessary complexity and questions as to how to interpret each character when encountered alone.</sentence> <sentence>To simplify matters, plain text files on Unix and Amiga systems use line feeds alone to separate lines.</sentence> <sentence>Similarly, older Macintosh systems, among others, use only carriage returns in plain text files.</sentence> <sentence>Various<space/><link><target>Digital Equipment Corporation</target><part>DEC</part></link><space/>operating systems used both characters to mark the end of a line, perhaps for compatibility with<space/><link><target>Teleprinter</target><part>teletypes</part></link>, and this de facto standard was copied in the<space/><link><target>CP/M</target></link><space/>operating system and then in<space/><link><target>MS-DOS</target></link><space/>and eventually<space/><link><target>Microsoft Windows</target></link>.</sentence> <sentence><link synthetic="true"><target>End-of-transmission character</target><part>Transmission</part></link> of text over the<space/><link><target>Internet</target></link>, for protocols as<space/><link><target>E-mail</target></link><space/>and the<space/><link><target>World Wide Web</target></link>, uses both characters.</sentence></paragraph><paragraph><sentence>The <link synthetic="true"><target>Digital Equipment Corporation</target><part>DEC</part></link> operating systems, along with <link synthetic="true"><target>CP/M</target></link>, tracked file length only in units of disk blocks and used <link synthetic="true"><target>Control-Z</target></link> (SUB) to mark the end of the actual text in the file (also done for <link synthetic="true"><target>CP/M</target></link> compatibility in some cases in <link synthetic="true"><target>MS-DOS</target></link>, though <link synthetic="true"><target>MS-DOS</target></link> has always recorded exact file-lengths).</sentence> <sentence><link synthetic="true"><target>character (computing)</target><part>Text</part></link><space/><link><target>string (computer science)</target><part>strings</part></link><space/>ending with the<space/><link><target>null character</target></link><space/>are known as<space/><link><target>ASCIZ</target></link><space/>or<space/><link><target>C string</target><trail>s</trail></link>.</sentence></paragraph><table class="wikitable" style="text-align: the<space/><link><target>Internet Assigned Numbers Authority</target></link><space/>registry of character sets<extension extension_name="ref" name="IANA"/><space/>recognize the following case-insensitive aliases for <link synthetic="true"><target>ASCII</target></link> as suitable for use on the <link synthetic="true"><target>Internet</target></link>:<xhtml:div style="-moz-column-count:2; column-count:2;"><list type="bullet"><listitem><sentence><link synthetic="true"><target>ANSI escape code</target><part>ANSI</part></link>_X3.4-1968 (canonical name)</sentence></listitem><listitem>iso-ir-6</listitem><listitem><sentence><link synthetic="true"><target>ANSI escape code</target><part>ANSI</part></link>_X3.4-1986</sentence></listitem><listitem><sentence>ISO_646.irv:1991</sentence></listitem><listitem><sentence><link synthetic="true"><target>ASCII</target></link> (with <link synthetic="true"><target>ASCII</target></link>-7 and <link synthetic="true"><target>ASCII</target></link>-8 (preferred<space/><link><target>MIME</target></link><space/>name<extension extension_name="ref" name="IANA">Internet Assigned Numbers Authority (May 14, 2007). "<link type="external" href="http://www.iana.org/assignments/character-sets">Character Sets</link>". Accessed 2008-04-14.</extension>)</sentence></listitem><listitem>us</listitem><listitem><sentence>IBM367</sentence></listitem><listitem>cp367</listitem><listitem>csASCII</listitem></list></xhtml:div></sentence></paragraph><paragraph><sentence>Of these, the IANA encourages use of the name "US-<link synthetic="true"><target>ASCII</target></link>" for<space/><link><target>Internet</target></link><space/>uses of <link synthetic="true"><target>ASCII</target></link>.</sentence> <sentence>One often finds this in the optional "charset" parameter in the Content-Type header of some<space/><link><target>MIME</target></link><space/>messages, in the equivalent "meta" element of some<space/><link><target>HTML</target></link><space/>documents, and in the encoding declaration part of the prologue of some<space/><link><target>XML</target></link><space/>documents.</sentence></paragraph><heading level="2">Variants</heading><paragraph><sentence>As computer technology spread throughout the world, different standards bodies and corporations developed many variations of <link synthetic="true"><target>ASCII</target></link> in order to facilitate the expression of non-<link synthetic="true"><target>English alphabet</target><part>English</part></link> languages that used <link synthetic="true"><target>Mac OS Roman</target><part>Roman</part></link>-based alphabets.</sentence> <sentence>One could class some of these variations as "<link><target>Extended ASCII</target><part>ASCII extensions</part></link>", although some misuse that term to cover all variants, including those that do not preserve <link synthetic="true"><target>ASCII</target><part>ASCII's</part></link> character-map in the 7-bit range.</sentence></paragraph><paragraph><sentence>The<space/><link><target>PETSCII</target></link><space/><link synthetic="true"><target>telegraph</target><part>Code</part></link> used by<space/><link><target>Commodore International</target></link><space/>for their 8-bit systems is probably unique among post-1970 codes in being based on <link synthetic="true"><target>ASCII</target></link>-1963 instead of the far more common <link synthetic="true"><target>ASCII</target></link>-1967, such as found on the<space/><link><target>ZX Spectrum character set</target><part>ZX Spectrum</part></link><space/>computer.</sentence><space/><sentence><link><target>ATASCII</target><part>Atari</part></link><space/>and<space/><link><target>Galaksija#Character ROM</target><part>Galaksija</part></link><space/>computers also used <link synthetic="true"><target>ASCII</target></link> variants.</sentence></paragraph><heading level="3">Incompatibility vs interoperability</heading><paragraph><sentence>From early in its development,<extension extension_name="ref">"Specific Criteria," attachment to memo from R. W. Reach, "X3-2 Meeting -- September 14 and 15," September 18, 1961</extension><space/><link synthetic="true"><target>ASCII</target></link> was intended to be just one of several national variants of an international character code standard, ultimately published as<space/><link><target>ISO/IEC 646</target></link><space/>(1972), which would share most characters in common but assign other locally-useful characters to several code points reserved for "national use."</sentence> <sentence>However, the four years that elapsed between the publication of <link synthetic="true"><target>ASCII</target></link>-1963 and ISO's first acceptance of an international recommendation in 1967<extension extension_name="ref">R. Maréchal, ISO/TC 97 - Computers and Information Processing: Acceptance of Draft ISO Recommendation No. 1052, December 22, 1967</extension><space/>caused <link synthetic="true"><target>ASCII</target><part>ASCII's</part></link> choices for the national use characters to appear to be de facto standards for the world, leading to confusion and incompatibility once other countries did begin to make their own assignments to these code points.</sentence><space/></paragraph><paragraph><sentence><link synthetic="true"><target>ISO/IEC 646</target></link>, like <link synthetic="true"><target>ASCII</target></link>, was a 7-bit character set.</sentence> <sentence>It made no additional codes available, so the same code points encoded different characters in different countries.</sentence> <sentence><link synthetic="true"><target>ANSI escape code</target><part>Escape codes</part></link> were defined to indicate which national variant applied to a piece of text, but these were rarely used, so it was often impossible to know what variant to work with and therefore which character a code represented, and text-processing systems could generally cope with only one variant anyway.</sentence></paragraph><paragraph><sentence>Because the bracket and brace characters of <link synthetic="true"><target>ASCII</target></link> were assigned to "national use" code points that were used for accented letters in other national variants of <link synthetic="true"><target>ISO/IEC 646</target></link>, a German, French, or Swedish, etc., programmer had to get used to reading and writing<xhtml:br/><xhtml:code>ä aÄiÜ='Ön'; ü</xhtml:code><xhtml:br/>instead of<xhtml:br/><xhtml:code>{ a[i]='n'; }</xhtml:code><xhtml:br/><link><target>C trigraph</target><trail>s</trail></link><space/>were created to solve this issue in <link synthetic="true"><target>ANSI escape code</target><part>ANSI</part></link> C, although their late introduction and inconsistent implementation in compilers limited their use.</sentence></paragraph><paragraph><sentence>Eventually, as 8-, 16-, and 32-bit computers began to replace 18- and 36-bit computers as the norm, it became common to use an 8-bit byte to store each character in memory, providing an opportunity for extended, 8-bit, relatives of <link synthetic="true"><target>ASCII</target></link>, with the 128 additional characters providing room to avoid most of the ambiguity that had been necessary in 7-bit codes.</sentence></paragraph><paragraph><sentence>For example,<space/><link><target>IBM</target></link><space/>developed 8-bit<space/><link><target>code page</target><trail>s</trail></link>, such as<space/><link><target>code page 437</target></link>, which replaced the control-characters with graphic symbols such as<space/><link><target>smiley</target></link><space/>faces, and mapped additional graphic characters to the upper 128 positions.</sentence> <sentence><link synthetic="true"><target>operating system</target><part>Operating systems</part></link> such as<space/><link><target>DOS</target></link><space/>supported these code-pages, and manufacturers of<space/><link><target>IBM PC</target><trail>s</trail></link><space/>supported them in hardware.</sentence><space/><sentence><link><target>Digital Equipment Corporation</target></link><space/>developed the<space/><link><target>Multinational Character Set</target></link><space/>(<link synthetic="true"><target>Digital Equipment Corporation</target><part>DEC</part></link>-MCS) for use in the popular<space/><link><target>VT220</target></link><space/><link><target>computer terminal</target><part>terminal</part></link>.</sentence></paragraph><paragraph><sentence>Eight-bit standards such as<space/><link><target>ISO/IEC 8859</target></link><space/>(derived from the <link synthetic="true"><target>Digital Equipment Corporation</target><part>DEC</part></link>-MCS) and<space/><link><target>Mac OS Roman</target></link><space/>developed as true extensions of <link synthetic="true"><target>ASCII</target></link>, leaving the original character-mapping intact, but adding additional character definitions after the first 128 (i.e.</sentence>, 7-bit) characters. <sentence>This enabled representation of characters used in a broader range of languages.</sentence> <sentence>Because there were several competing 8-bit code standards, they continued to suffer from incompatibilities and limitations.</sentence> <sentence>Still,<space/><link><target>ISO/IEC 8859-1#ISO-8859-1</target><part>ISO-8859-1 (Latin 1)</part></link>, its variant<space/><link><target>Windows-1252</target></link><space/>(often mislabeled as <link synthetic="true"><target>ISO/IEC 8859-1#ISO-8859-1</target><part>ISO-8859-1</part></link>), and the original 7-bit <link synthetic="true"><target>ASCII</target></link> remain the most common character encodings in use today.</sentence></paragraph><heading level="3">Unicode</heading><paragraph><sentence><link><target>Unicode</target></link><space/>and the <link synthetic="true"><target>ISO/IEC 646</target><part>ISO/IEC</part></link> 10646<space/><link><target>Universal Character Set</target></link><space/>(UCS) have a much wider array of characters, and their various encoding forms have begun to supplant <link synthetic="true"><target>ISO/IEC 8859</target></link> and <link synthetic="true"><target>ASCII</target></link> rapidly in many environments.</sentence> <sentence>While <link synthetic="true"><target>ASCII</target></link> is limited to 128 characters, <link synthetic="true"><target>Unicode</target></link> and the UCS support more characters by separating the concepts of unique identification (using<space/><link><target>natural number</target><trail>s</trail></link><space/>called<space/><italics>code points</italics>) and encoding (to 8-, 16- or 32-bit binary formats, called<space/><link><target>UTF-8</target></link>,<space/><link><target>UTF-16</target></link><space/>and<space/><link><target>UTF-32</target></link>).</sentence></paragraph><paragraph><sentence>To permit backward compatibility, the 128 <link synthetic="true"><target>ASCII</target></link> and 256 <link synthetic="true"><target>ISO/IEC 8859-1#ISO-8859-1</target><part>ISO-8859-1 (Latin 1)</part></link> characters are assigned <link synthetic="true"><target>Unicode</target></link>/UCS code points that are the same as their codes in the earlier standards.</sentence> <sentence>Therefore, <link synthetic="true"><target>ASCII</target></link> can be considered a 7-bit encoding scheme for a very small subset of <link synthetic="true"><target>Unicode</target></link>/UCS, and, conversely, the <link synthetic="true"><target>UTF-8</target></link> encoding forms are binary-compatible with <link synthetic="true"><target>ASCII</target></link> for code points below 128, meaning every properly encoded <link synthetic="true"><target>ASCII</target></link> file is also a valid <link synthetic="true"><target>UTF-8</target></link> file.</sentence> <sentence>The other encoding forms resemble <link synthetic="true"><target>ASCII</target></link> in how they represent the first 128 characters of <link synthetic="true"><target>Unicode</target></link>, but use 16 or 32 bits per character, so they require conversion for compatibility.</sentence></paragraph><heading level="2">Order</heading><paragraph><sentence><link><target>Collation</target></link><space/>of data is sometimes done in <link synthetic="true"><target>ASCII</target></link>-code order rather than "standard" alphabetical order.</sentence> <sentence>The main deviations are:</sentence></paragraph><list type="bullet"><listitem>capitals come before lowercase letters, i.e. <sentence>"Z" before "a"</sentence></listitem><listitem>characters in extended character sets such as <sentence>"é" come after "z"</sentence></listitem></list><paragraph><sentence>The<space/><link><target>slang</target></link><space/>expression<space/><italics>ASCIIbetical</italics><space/>is sometimes used for this order.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref"><link type="external" href="http://www.pcmag.com/encyclopedia_term/0,2542,t=ASCIIbetical&amp;amp;i=38025,00.asp">ASCIIbetical definition</link>.<space/><italics><link><target>PC Magazine</target></link></italics>. Accessed 2008-04-14.</extension><sentence>In programming,<space/><italics>alphanumeric</italics><space/>sorting means to sort by numeric value, without regard for any character set.</sentence> <sentence>An alphanumerically sorted array of bytes will appear ASCIIbetically when viewed in an <link synthetic="true"><target>ASCII</target></link>-compatible character set.</sentence></paragraph><paragraph><sentence>A refined version of this order converts uppercase letters to lowercase before comparing <link synthetic="true"><target>ASCII</target></link> values.</sentence></paragraph><heading level="2">References</heading><paragraph><template name="reflist">\n<param name="1">2</param>\n</template></paragraph><heading level="2">Further reading</heading><list type="bullet"><listitem><sentence>R.W.</sentence> <sentence><link synthetic="true"><target>Bob Bemer</target><part>Bemer</part></link>, "A Proposal for <link synthetic="true"><target>character encoding</target><part>Character</part></link> <link synthetic="true"><target>telegraph</target><part>Code</part></link> <link synthetic="true"><target>Backward compatibility</target><part>Compatibility</part></link>," <link synthetic="true"><target>telecommunication</target><part>Communications</part></link> of the ACM, Vol.</sentence> 3. <sentence>No.</sentence> 2, <sentence>February, 1960, pp.</sentence> 71-72</listitem><listitem><template name="cite news">\n<param name="title">History and impact of computer standards</param>\n<param name="author">G.S. name="Link FA">\n<param (tekenset)</target></link><link><target>ja:ASCII</target></link><link><target>no:ASCII</target></link><link><target>nn:ASCII</target></link><link><target>nds:ASCII</target></link><link><target>pl:ASCII</target></link><link><target>pt:ASCII</target></link><link><target>ksh:ASCII</target></link><link><target>ro:ASCII</target></link><link><target>ru:ASCII</target></link><link><target>sco:ASCII</target></link><link><target>sq:ASCII</target></link><link><target>simple:ASCII</target></link><link><target>sk:ASCII</target></link><link><target>sl:ASCII</target></link><link><target>sr:ASCII</target></link><link><target>fi:ASCII</target></link><link><target>sv:ASCII</target></link><link><target>kab:ASCII</target></link><link><target>th:แอสกี</target></link><link><target>vi:ASCII</target></link><link><target>tr:ASCII</target></link><link><target>uk:ASCII</target></link><link><target>ur:امریکی معیاری رمز براۓ اطلاعاتی تبادلہ</target></link><link><target>zh:ASCII</target></link></sentence></paragraph></article></articles>	frameAmerican Standard Code for Information Interchange (ASCII),  is a character-encoding scheme based on the English alphabet. ASCII codes represent text in computer, communications equipment, and other devices that work with text. Most modern character-encoding schemes—which support many more characters than did the original—have a historical basis in ASCII.\n\nHistorically, ASCII developed from telegraphic codes. Its first commercial use was as a seven-bit teleprinter code promoted by Bell data services. Work on ASCII formally began October 6, 1960, with the first meeting of the ASA X3.2 subcommittee. The first edition of the standard was published in 1963, a major revision in 1967, and the most recent update in 1986. Compared to earlier telegraph codes, the proposed Bell code and ASCII were both ordered for more convenient sorting (i.e., alphabetization) of lists, and added features for devices other than teleprinters.\n\nASCII includes definitions for 128 characters: 33 are non-printing, mostly-obsolete control character that affect how text is processed; 94 are printable characters, and the space is considered an invisible graphic. The ASCII character-encoding scheme is the most-commonly-used character set on the Internet.\n\nthumbThe American Standard Code for Information Interchange (ASCII) was developed under the auspices of a committee of the American Standards Association, called the X3 committee, by its X3.2 (later X3L2) subcommittee, and later by that subcommittee's X3.2.4 working group. The ASA became the United States of America Standards Institute or USASI and ultimately the American National Standards Institute.\n\nThe X3.2 subcommittee designed ASCII based on earlier teleprinter encoding systems. Like other character encoding, ASCII specifies a correspondence between digital bit patterns and character symbols (i.e. grapheme and control character). This allows digital devices to communicate with each other and to process, store, and communicate character-oriented information such as written language. Before ASCII was developed, the encodings in use included 26 alphabetic characters, 10 numerical digit, and from 11 to 25 special graphic symbols. To include all these, and control characters compatible with the Comité Consultatif International Téléphonique et Télégraphique standard, Fieldata and early EBCDIC, more than 64 codes were required in ASCII.\n\nThe committee debated the possibility of a shift key function (like the Baudot code), which would allow more than 64 codes to be represented by six bits. In a shifted code, some character codes determine choices between options for the following character codes. This allows compact encoding, but is less reliable for data transmission; an error in transmitting the shift code typically makes a long part of the transmission unreadable. The standards committee decided against shifting, and so ASCII required at least a seven-bit code.\n\nThe committee considered an eight-bit code, since eight bits would allow two four-bit patterns to efficiently encode two digits with binary coded decimal. However this would require all data transmission to send eight bits when seven could suffice. The committee voted to use a seven-bit code to minimize costs associated with data transmission. Since perforated tape at the time could record eight bits in one position, this also allowed for a parity bit for error checking if desired. Machines with octets as the native data type that did not use parity checking typically set the eighth bit to 0.\n\nThe code itself was structured so that most control codes were together, and all graphic codes were together. The first two columns (32 positions) were reserved for control characters. The "space" character had to come before graphics to make sorting algorithm easy, so it became position 32. The committee decided it was important to support upper case 64-character alphabets, and chose to structure ASCII so it could easily be reduced to a usable 64-character set of graphic codes. Lower case letters were therefore not interleaved with upper case. To keep options open for lower case letters and other graphics, the special and numeric codes were placed before the letters, and the letter 'A' was placed in position 65 to match the draft of the corresponding British standard. The digits 0–9 were placed so they correspond to values in binary prefixed with 011, making conversion with binary-coded decimal straightforward.\n\nMany of the non-alphanumeric characters were positioned to correspond to their shifted position on typewriters. Thus #, $ and % were placed to correspond to 3, 4, and 5 in the adjacent column. The parentheses could not correspond to 9 and 0, however, because the place corresponding to 0 was taken by the space character. Since many European typewriters placed the parentheses with 8 and 9, those corresponding positions were chosen for the parentheses. The @ symbol was not used in continental Europe and the committee expected it would be replaced by an accented À in the French variation, so the @ was placed in position 64 next to the letter A.\n\nThe control codes felt essential for data transmission were the start of message (SOM), end of address (EOA), end of message (EOM), end of transmission (EOT), "who are you?" (WRU), "are you?" (RU), a reserved device control (DC0), synchronous idle (SYNC), and acknowledge (ACK). These were positioned to maximize the Hamming distance between their bit patterns.\n\nWith the other special characters and control codes filled in, ASCII was published as ASA X3.4-1963, leaving 28 code positions without any assigned meaning, reserved for future standardization, and one unassigned control code. It now seems obvious that these positions should have been assigned to the lower case alphabet, but there was some debate at the time whether there should be more control characters instead. The indecision did not last long: in May 1963 the CCITT Working Party on the New Telegraph Alphabet proposed to assign lower case characters to columns 6 and 7, and International Organization for Standardization TC 97 SC 2 voted in October to incorporate the change into its draft standard. The X3.2.4 task group voted its approval for the change to ASCII at its May 1963 meeting. Locating the lowercase letters in columns 6 and 7 caused the characters to differ in bit pattern from the upper case by a single bit, which simplified case-insensitive character matching and the construction of keyboards and printers.\n\nThe X3 committee made other changes, including other new characters (the curly bracket and vertical line characters), renaming some control characters (SOM became start of header (SOH)) and moving or removing others (RU was removed). ASCII was subsequently updated as USASI X3.4-1967, then USASI X3.4-1968, ANSI X3.4-1977, and finally, ANSI X3.4-1986 (the first two are occasionally retronamed ANSI X3.4-1967, and ANSI X3.4-1968).\n\nThe X3 committee also addressed how ASCII should be transmitted (least significant bit first), and how it should be recorded on perforated tape. They proposed a 9-track standard for magnetic tape, and attempted to deal with some forms of punched card formats.\n\nASCII itself first entered commercial use in 1963 as a seven-bit teleprinter code for American Telephone &amp; Telegraph's TWX (Teletype Wide-area eXchange) network. TWX originally used the earlier five-bit Baudot code, which was also used by the competing Telex teleprinter system. Bob Bemer introduced features such as the escape sequence. His British colleague Hugh McGregor Ross helped to popularize this work—according to Bemer, "so much so that the code that was to become ASCII was first called the Bemer-Ross Code in Europe".\n\nOn March 11, 1968, U.S. President Lyndon B. Johnson mandated that all computers purchased by the United States federal government support ASCII, stating:\n\nOther international standards bodies have ratified character encodings such as ISO/IEC 646 that are identical or nearly identical to ASCII, with extensions for characters outside the English alphabet and symbols used outside the United States, such as the symbol for the United Kingdom's pound sterling (£). Almost every country needed an adapted version of ASCII since ASCII only suited the needs of the USA and a few other countries. For example, Canada had its own version that supported French characters. Other adapted encodings include ISCII (India), VISCII (Vietnam), and YUSCII (Yugoslavia). Although these encodings are sometimes referred to as ASCII, true ASCII is strictly defined only by ANSI standard.\n\nASCII was incorporated into the Unicode character set as the first 128 symbols, so the ASCII characters have the same numeric codes in both sets. This allows UTF-8 to be backward compatible with ASCII, a significant advantage.\n\nAsteroid 3568 ASCII is named after the character encoding.\n\nASCII reserves the first 32 codes (numbers 0–31 decimal) for control character: codes originally intended not to carry printable information, but rather to control devices (such as printer) that make use of ASCII, or to provide meta-information about data streams such as those stored on magnetic tape. For example, character 10 represents the "line feed" function (which causes a printer to advance its paper), and character 8 represents "backspace". RFC 2822 refers to control characters that do not include carriage return, line feed or white space as non-whitespace control characters. Except for the control characters that prescribe elementary line-oriented formatting, ASCII does not define any mechanism for describing the structure or appearance of text within a document. Other schemes, such as markup language, address page and document layout and formatting.\n\nThe original ASCII standard used only short descriptive phrases for each control character. The ambiguity this left was sometimes intentional (where a character would be used slightly differently on a terminal link than on a data stream) and sometimes more accidental (such as what "delete" means).\n\nProbably the most influential single device on the interpretation of these characters was the ASR-33 Teletype series, which was a printing terminal with an available paper tape reader/punch option. Paper tape was a very popular medium for long-term program storage up through the 1980s, lower cost and in some ways less fragile than magnetic tape. In particular, the Teletype 33 machine assignments for codes 17 (Control-Q, DC1, also known as XON), 19 (Control-S, DC3, also known as XOFF), and 127 (DELete) became de-facto standards. Because the keytop for the O key also showed a left-arrow symbol (from ASCII-1963, which had this character instead of underscore), a noncompliant use of code 15 (Control-O, Shift In) interpreted as "delete previous character" was also adopted by many early timesharing systems but eventually faded out.\n\nThe use of Control-S (XOFF, an abbreviation for "transmit off") as a handshaking signal warning a sender to stop transmission because of impending overflow, and Control-Q (XON, "transmit on") to resume sending, persists to this day in many systems as a manual output control technique. On some systems Control-S retains its meaning but Control-Q is replaced by a second Control-S to resume output.\n\nCode 127 is officially named "delete" but the Teletype label was "rubout". Since the original standard gave no detailed interpretation for most control codes, interpretations of this code varied. The original Teletype meaning, and the intent of the standard, was to make it an ignored character, the same as NUL (all zeroes). This was specifically useful for paper tape, because punching the all-ones bit pattern on top of an existing mark would obliterate it. Tapes designed to be "hand edited" could even be produced with spaces of extra NULs (blank tape) so that a block of characters could be "rubbed out" and then replacements put into the empty space.\n\nAs video terminals began to replace printing ones, the value of the "rubout" character was lost. DEC systems, for example, interpreted "Delete" to mean "remove the character before the cursor," and this interpretation also became common in Unix systems. Most other systems used "Backspace" for that meaning and used "Delete" to mean "remove the character at the cursor". That latter interpretation is the most common today.\n\nMany more of the control codes have taken on meanings quite different from their original ones. The "escape" character (code 27), for example, was originally intended to allow sending other control characters as literals instead of invoking their meaning. This is the same meaning of "escape" encountered in URL encodings, C language strings, and other systems where certain characters have a reserved meaning. Over time this meaning has been co-opted and has eventually drifted. In modern use, an ESC sent to the terminal usually indicates the start of a command sequence, usually in the form of a so-called "ANSI escape code" (or, more properly, a "Control Sequence Introducer") beginning with ESC followed by a "[" (left-bracket) character. An ESC sent from the terminal is most often used as an "out of band" character used to terminate an operation, as in the TECO and vi text editors.\n\nThe inherent ambiguity of many control characters, combined with their historical usage, created problems when transferring "plain text" files between systems. The clearest example of this is the newline problem on various operating system. On printing terminals there is no question that you terminate a line of text with both "Carriage Return" and "Linefeed". The first returns the printing carriage to the beginning of the line and the second advances to the next line without moving the carriage. However, requiring two characters to mark the end of a line introduced unnecessary complexity and questions as to how to interpret each character when encountered alone. To simplify matters, plain text files on Unix and Amiga systems use line feeds alone to separate lines. Similarly, older Macintosh systems, among others, use only carriage returns in plain text files. Various DEC operating systems used both characters to mark the end of a line, perhaps for compatibility with teletypes, and this de facto standard was copied in the CP/M operating system and then in MS-DOS and eventually Microsoft Windows. Transmission of text over the Internet, for protocols as E-mail and the World Wide Web, uses both characters.\n\nThe DEC operating systems, along with CP/M, tracked file length only in units of disk blocks and used Control-Z (SUB) to mark the end of the actual text in the file (also done for CP/M compatibility in some cases in MS-DOS, though MS-DOS has always recorded exact file-lengths). Text strings ending with the null character are known as ASCIZ or C string.\n\nCode 32, the "space" character, denotes the space between words, as produced by the space-bar of a keyboard. The "space" character is considered an invisible graphic rather than a control character. Codes 33 to 126, known as the printable characters, represent letters, digits, punctuation marks, and a few miscellaneous symbols.\n\nSeven-bit ASCII provided seven "national" characters and, if the combined hardware and software permit, can use overstrikes to simulate some additional international characters: in such a scenario a backspace can precede a grave accent (which the American and British standards, but only those standards, also call "opening single quotation mark"), a backtick, or a breath mark (inverted vel).\n\nA June 1992 RFC and the Internet Assigned Numbers Authority registry of character sets recognize the following case-insensitive aliases for ASCII as suitable for use on the Internet:\n\nOf these, the IANA encourages use of the name "US-ASCII" for Internet uses of ASCII. One often finds this in the optional "charset" parameter in the Content-Type header of some MIME messages, in the equivalent "meta" element of some HTML documents, and in the encoding declaration part of the prologue of some XML documents.\n\nAs computer technology spread throughout the world, different standards bodies and corporations developed many variations of ASCII in order to facilitate the expression of non-English languages that used Roman-based alphabets. One could class some of these variations as "ASCII extensions", although some misuse that term to cover all variants, including those that do not preserve ASCII's character-map in the 7-bit range.\n\nThe PETSCII Code used by Commodore International for their 8-bit systems is probably unique among post-1970 codes in being based on ASCII-1963 instead of the far more common ASCII-1967, such as found on the ZX Spectrum computer. Atari and Galaksija computers also used ASCII variants.\n\nFrom early in its development, ASCII was intended to be just one of several national variants of an international character code standard, ultimately published as ISO/IEC 646 (1972), which would share most characters in common but assign other locally-useful characters to several code points reserved for "national use." However, the four years that elapsed between the publication of ASCII-1963 and ISO's first acceptance of an international recommendation in 1967 caused ASCII's choices for the national use characters to appear to be de facto standards for the world, leading to confusion and incompatibility once other countries did begin to make their own assignments to these code points. \n\nISO/IEC 646, like ASCII, was a 7-bit character set. It made no additional codes available, so the same code points encoded different characters in different countries. Escape codes were defined to indicate which national variant applied to a piece of text, but these were rarely used, so it was often impossible to know what variant to work with and therefore which character a code represented, and text-processing systems could generally cope with only one variant anyway.\n\nBecause the bracket and brace characters of ASCII were assigned to "national use" code points that were used for accented letters in other national variants of ISO/IEC 646, a German, French, or Swedish, etc., programmer had to get used to reading and writinginstead ofC trigraph were created to solve this issue in ANSI C, although their late introduction and inconsistent implementation in compilers limited their use.\n\nEventually, as 8-, 16-, and 32-bit computers began to replace 18- and 36-bit computers as the norm, it became common to use an 8-bit byte to store each character in memory, providing an opportunity for extended, 8-bit, relatives of ASCII, with the 128 additional characters providing room to avoid most of the ambiguity that had been necessary in 7-bit codes.\n\nFor example, IBM developed 8-bit code page, such as code page 437, which replaced the control-characters with graphic symbols such as smiley faces, and mapped additional graphic characters to the upper 128 positions. Operating systems such as DOS supported these code-pages, and manufacturers of IBM PC supported them in hardware. Digital Equipment Corporation developed the Multinational Character Set (DEC-MCS) for use in the popular VT220 terminal.\n\nEight-bit standards such as ISO/IEC 8859 (derived from the DEC-MCS) and Mac OS Roman developed as true extensions of ASCII, leaving the original character-mapping intact, but adding additional character definitions after the first 128 (i.e., 7-bit) characters. This enabled representation of characters used in a broader range of languages. Because there were several competing 8-bit code standards, they continued to suffer from incompatibilities and limitations. Still, ISO-8859-1 (Latin 1), its variant Windows-1252 (often mislabeled as ISO-8859-1), and the original 7-bit ASCII remain the most common character encodings in use today.\n\nUnicode and the ISO/IEC 10646 Universal Character Set (UCS) have a much wider array of characters, and their various encoding forms have begun to supplant ISO/IEC 8859 and ASCII rapidly in many environments. While ASCII is limited to 128 characters, Unicode and the UCS support more characters by separating the concepts of unique identification (using natural number called code points) and encoding (to 8-, 16- or 32-bit binary formats, called UTF-8, UTF-16 and UTF-32).\n\nTo permit backward compatibility, the 128 ASCII and 256 ISO-8859-1 (Latin 1) characters are assigned Unicode/UCS code points that are the same as their codes in the earlier standards. Therefore, ASCII can be considered a 7-bit encoding scheme for a very small subset of Unicode/UCS, and, conversely, the UTF-8 encoding forms are binary-compatible with ASCII for code points below 128, meaning every properly encoded ASCII file is also a valid UTF-8 file. The other encoding forms resemble ASCII in how they represent the first 128 characters of Unicode, but use 16 or 32 bits per character, so they require conversion for compatibility.\n\nCollation of data is sometimes done in ASCII-code order rather than "standard" alphabetical order. The main deviations are:\n\nThe slang expression ASCIIbetical is sometimes used for this order.In programming, alphanumeric sorting means to sort by numeric value, without regard for any character set. An alphanumerically sorted array of bytes will appear ASCIIbetically when viewed in an ASCII-compatible character set.\n\nA refined version of this order converts uppercase letters to lowercase before comparing ASCII values.\n\n

name="1">Traditional animation</param>\n</template></sentence></paragraph><paragraph><sentence>(Also called<space/><link><target>cel animation</target></link>) <link synthetic="true"><target>traditional animation</target><part>Traditional animation</part></link> was the process used for most animated films of the 20th century.</sentence> <sentence>The individual frames of a traditionally animated film are photographs of drawings, which are first drawn on paper.</sentence> <sentence>To create the illusion of movement, each drawing differs slightly from the one before it.</sentence> <sentence><link synthetic="true"><target>The Animator's Survival Kit</target><part>The animators</part></link>' drawings are traced or photocopied onto transparent acetate sheets called<space/><link><target>cel</target><trail>s</trail></link>, which are filled in with paints in assigned colors or tones on the side opposite the line drawings.</sentence> <sentence>The completed character cels are photographed one-by-one onto motion picture film against a painted background by a<space/><link><target>rostrum camera</target></link>.</sentence></paragraph><paragraph><sentence>The traditional cel animation process became obsolete by the beginning of the 21st century.</sentence> <sentence>Today, animators' color the drawings and simulate camera movement and effects.</sentence> <sentence>The final animated piece is output to one of several delivery mediums, including traditional<space/><link><target>35 mm film</target></link><space/>and newer media such as<space/><link><target>digital video</target></link>.</sentence> <sentence>The "look" of traditional cel animation is still preserved, and the<space/><link><target>character animator</target><trail>s</trail></link>' work has remained essentially the same over the past 70 years.</sentence> <sentence>Some animation producers have used the term "tradigital" to describe cel animation which makes extensive use of computer technology.</sentence></paragraph><paragraph><sentence>Examples of traditionally animated feature films
